The Editors' "Black Gold"
One of the most popular - in our country - British bands is dynamically in the forefront with a collection of its biggest hits and some new songs
04 Nov 2019, 13:03 by Nastos George
A few days ago the album "Black Gold" of the beloved Greek editors was released, a collection of their biggest hits that includes three brand new songs: "Upside Down", "Frankenstein" and the homonymous, extremely dramatic track. . The British band has also recently announced that they will be touring Europe early next year. Of course, Greece is among the countries to visit: they will be performing at the Principal Theater in Thessaloniki on March 27 and at the Tae Kwon Do Stadium in Athens on March 28. Vima spoke with band drummer Edward Lay about their progress to date and the major changes in the music industry.

14 years after your debut in discography, you release a best of. How did you make that decision?

"You know, at first we were all worried about why the release of a best of makes you feel old and no one wants to feel that way. The song selection process, however, gave us the opportunity not only to reflect on what we did and celebrate but also to get into the process of writing some new songs and releasing them quickly. That is, one understands listening to "Black Gold" what made us the band we are and where we are today. "

So you haven't had an account to date?

“Sometimes the daily obligations and requirements of daily living monopolize your time and you have no way of knowing what it has accomplished. We've had so many unique experiences that others are just dreaming of: from the countries we've played to the fact that we've been on the same stage with our idols, REM or The Cure, for example. "

For the data of the season you are considered a long-lived band. What made you resistant to the passage of time?

“We always made decisions that would be of mutual benefit and respected the opinion of every member of the band. Our thought has always been to improve, not to become more famous or successful. We were very consciously abstaining from the game of publicity and claimed our creative freedom without compromising by working, for example, with partners we did not appreciate. "

How important were you growing up in Birmingham in terms of your music?

"This city has been carrying on its industrial past so strongly and has now evolved into an interesting multicultural society. It's not the most beautiful place in the world, and I think the locals know it and that's why they feel humble. We had this element in our beginning as well. We knew that if we were to stand out in the competitive landscape of music we would have to be very good. "

Do you really have a favorite track on the album?

"I don't know if it's such a choice today that anyone can make their own Spotify list with their favorites. I like the audio versions of some of the songs, they create very different emotions than the original ones, and I like the b-side of "Let Your Good Heart Lead You Home" in a song from our first album. We recorded it with some Elbow members - the way it was created and recorded was crucial to our modus operandi. This is a very important song on our track and I am very happy to have found a place on the record. "

Since you mentioned Spotify, how do you feel about the music industry today?

"When we started out, the support from the radio and the tour we did with Franz Ferdinand helped us get to know the so-called big audience. Not all of this is necessary today but I really have no idea how young artists stand out. It doesn't hurt me to not have to be a record label and be able to release your own music. If you are smart and work hard I think you will achieve something. "
